in_class_description: Tropical interior desert with sparse vegetation
in_class_description_detail: Desert pampa in the interior of the regions of Arica and Parinacota, Tarapacá and Antofagasta, between 600 and 2,100 m altitude, ultrahyperarid mesotropical and hyperoceanic lower supratropical ultrahyperarid bioclimatic floors. Area that almost completely lacks plant life, except in some sectors with the presence of brackish underground water table where a halophilic scrub dominated by Tessaria absinthioides is observed. It is possible that there are more plant communities, but botanical knowledge about these areas is very poorly developed in Chile, so information on the floristic composition is not available.
efg_description: The most extreme of all desert ecosystems, hyper-arid deserts are limited by very dry and often windy conditions with high temperatures and sandy or stony soils. Dry periods may be prolonged for several years. Vegetation is characterised by very low densities of small drought-tolerant perennial plants known as xerophytes, very slow growing species with adaptations to drought such as extensive root systems and water storage tissues. Some of these plants may acquire much of their moisture from fogs. Ephemeral plants occur in some regions, but are less common than in other desert systems. Microbial biofilms are important decomposers. Drought tolerant reptiles and invertebrates are the main faunal groups, along with occasional nomadic mammals and birds, in simple foodwebs.

in_class_description: Tropical coastal dunes of Tillandsia landbeckii - T. marconae
in_class_description_detail: Inland areas close to the coast of the Arica and Parinacota and Tarapacá regions between 800 and 1,400 m, ultra-hyperarid hyperoceanic mesotropical bioclimatic floor. The tillandsiales described for the interior of Caldera (Atacama Region) are integrated as part of the variability of ecosystem 15 (interior tropical-Mediterranean desert scrub of Skytanthus acutus - Atriplex deserticola). It has been suggested that the dynamics of this type of vegetation is cyclical, beginning with an expansion of the plants during their growth in the direction of the incident fog. Growth is strongly controlled by the nutrient supply from the fog. As new tissue is generated, the older parts not exposed to the fog become senescent and eventually die, but they decompose very slowly, so that they persist for a long time until they are finally buried under the sand. Dating of buried remains has shown that the formations may be as old as 3,000 years.

in_class_description: Tropical coastal ephemeral forb vegetation of Nolana adansonii - N. lycioides
in_class_description_detail: Low coastal zone in the south of the Tarapacá and Antofagasta regions, 0–400 m, upper thermotropical and lower mesotropical ultra-hyperarid hyperoceanic bioclimatic levels. Plants are observed only after intense rains associated with El Niño events, probably from seed banks generated during the previous rainy period. In Nolana jaffuelii, it has been shown that there are physical and physiological mechanisms that would allow seeds to remain dormant for long periods awaiting favorable conditions for germination.

in_class_description_detail: Large ravines in the desert pampas of the regions of Arica and Parinacota, Tarapacá and Antofagasta, 0–1,500 m, lower hyperoceanic ultra-hyperarid mesotropical bioclimatic zone. There is no known information about its natural dynamics. Most of the surfaces originally covered by this type of vegetation are now subject to agricultural use, which has ended up replacing practically all of the natural areas in the ravines.

in_class_description: Tropical interior desert scrub of Atriplex atacamensis - Tessaria absinthioides
in_class_description_detail: Large salt flats in the Tarapacá (600–900 m) and Antofagasta (2,400–2,500 m) regions, in the ultra-hyperarid mesotropical and hyperarid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. | Tall, phreatophilous scrubland dominated by the shrubs Atriplex atacamensis and Tessaria absinthioides and the grass Distichlis spicata. Its presence, associated with salt flats, is determined by the existence of a water table that provides sufficient humidity to compensate for the water deficit caused by the lack of rainfall, despite which it has been considered an independent unit. Occasionally, it is possible to observe the presence of the thorn trees Prosopis alba and Geoffroea decorticans. Because it is edaphically conditioned, it is not possible to recognize zonal and intrazonal communities.
efg_description: Semi-desert steppes on all continents are dominated by perennial shrubs, often with semi-fleshy or velvety foliage, and tussock grasses interspersed with bare ground. Low variable rainfall and extreme temperatures favour flora and fauna with drought and stress-tolerance adaptations, such as deep roots and nomadism. Growth and reproduction of shrubs and grasses is varies with rainfall, the cover of grass diminishing to near zero in extended droughts. Grass cover also depends on soil fertility and grazing animals, which may also limit shrub recruitment and growth. These steppes are among the most productive of desert ecosystems, with relatively abundant small and large herbivorous and seed-eating mammals supporting bird and mammal predators and scavengers.

in_class_description: Tropical coastal desert scrub of Nolana sedifolia / Eulychnia iquiquensis
in_class_description_detail: Lands practically devoid of vascular plants, where it is only possible to observe enclaves of coastal vegetation in the high mountainous areas near the coast, where there is an incidence of fog, such as in Alto Junín, Punta Madrid and Cerro Camaraca. Regenerative dynamics must be associated with the scarce precipitation events that occur. It has been suggested that in the prolonged absence of such events, the dominant species, especially Cactaceae, tend to disappear, which is reflected in the large number of dead individuals observed. However, there are no known antecedents on the existence of seed banks or the longevity of the species, elements that could interact with sporadic precipitation events and model the dynamics of vegetation at time scales not yet studied.
efg_name: Succulent or Thorny deserts and semi-deserts
efg_description: Succulent or Thorny deserts and semi-deserts are restricted in their occurrence to parts of the Americas, Africa, Madagascar and south Asia. They have a sparse cover of typical cactus-like plants and other slow-growing spiny and succulent species, on stony low-nutrient soils. Many of these plants store water in their stems and have deep roots. Short-lived plant species emerge after rains from dormant organs or soil seed banks. Plants and animals tolerate extreme summer temperatures and mild winters. Nocturnal and burrowing mammals are able to avoid extreme temperatures. Diverse opportunistic invertebrates and reptiles occur, along with small numbers of large-ranging ungulates.

in_class_description: Tropical-Mediterranean coastal desert scrub of Ephedra breana / Eulychnia iquiquensis
in_class_description_detail:
Coastal hills in the north of the Antofagasta region, between 300 and 1,300 m above sea level in the ultra-hyperarid mesotropical, ultra-hyperarid mesomediterranean and marginally in the ultra-hyperarid hyperoceanic upper thermo-Mediterranean bioclimatic zone. | ​​Extremely xeromorphic open scrubland with columnar succulents, dominated by Ephedra breana, Solanum brachyantherum and Eulychnia iquiquensis, which marks the physiognomy of the vegetation, with the participation of the shrubs Frankenia chilensis, Nolana balsamiflua, N. clivicola, Solanum chilense. Much of the territory of this zone develops in relief conditions that favor the condensation of fog. In the Cerro Moreno - La Chimba area, Heliotropium eremogenum and Lycium leiostemum are important. This last area has a particular species composition, but is floristically related to the vegetation of the Tocopilla area. 

Rainfall occurs in this area every 4 to 7 years. During dry periods, some shrubs and cacti survive thanks to the influence of fog and dry out over the years due to the permanent water shortage. However, herbaceous plants disappear completely. During rainy years, all plants renew their tissues and flower, only to experience a long period of drought again.

in_class_description: Tropical-Mediterranean coastal desert scrub of Copiapoa boliviana - Heliotropium pycnophyllum
in_class_description_detail: Extremely xeromorphic open scrubland dominated by Heliotropium pycnophyllum and Nolana peruviana, with the presence of Copiapoa boliviana. Vegetation cover is generally very low, but increases slightly during the wettest years due to the emergence of herbaceous plants. There are large areas devoid of vascular plants. There are very few specific records on this vegetation level. There are no precedents, but it is presumed that it must be determined by the very occasional occurrence of winter precipitation.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal desert scrub of Gypothamnium pinifolium - Heliotropium pycnophyllum
in_class_description_detail: Low coastal zone in the north of the Atacama region and south of the Antofagasta region, 0-350 m. The dominant shrub species in this ecosystem and the cacti are xerophytes that are very well adapted to extremely arid conditions, and are therefore able to maintain their vegetative structures during dry years, when herbaceous plants are almost completely absent. In contrast, rainy years show a greater abundance of herbaceous plants and a much greater development of the reproductive structures of shrubs and cacti.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal desert scrub of Euphorbia lactiflua / Eulychnia iquiquensis
in_class_description_detail: Middle slopes of the western slope of the coastal hills in the south of the Antofagasta region, 300-1000 m. Very similar to that described for ecosystem 11 (Mediterranean coastal desert scrub of Euphorbia lactiflua / Eulychnia saint-pieana), in which the abundance of herbaceous plants is determined by the intensity of rainfall. However, and as in the rest of the ecosystems identified for the desert, there are no specific studies on the regenerative dynamics of the dominant perennial species.

Controlled by the occurrence of precipitation, which determines the abundance of the herbaceous stratum. The scarcity of annual plants indicates that fog partially compensates for the water deficit during dry years, which, however, show a lower abundance of herbaceous plants than in rainy years.

in_class_description_detail: Eastern area of ​​the Coastal mountain range in the north of the Atacama region and south of Antofagasta, between 400 and 1,300 m, associated with the ultra-hyperarid hyperoceanic thermo-Mediterranean and lower mesomediterranean bioclimatic zone. Only determined by the occasional occurrence of rainfall, which triggers the development of the herbaceous carpet. The shrubs are strongly adapted to conditions of extreme aridity, so that, under local conditions of favourable humidity, they can develop their reproductive structures every year.

in_class_description_detail: Low coastal area of ​​the center of the Atacama region, between 0 and 200 m, in the lower thermo-Mediterranean ultrahyperarid and hyperarid hyperoceanic bioclimatic floors. Strongly determined, as in the ecosystems described above, by the interannual variability of rainfall. The driest years show almost completely absent vegetation, with most shrubs with their external tissues dry, while in rainy years a large quantity of herbaceous, annual and perennial plants and shrubs with their external tissues renewed can be observed.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal desert scrub of Oxalis virgosa / Eulychnia breviflora
in_class_description_detail: Western coastal areas of the central Atacama region, 0–400 m, ultra-hyperarid thermo-Mediterranean and hyperarid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. The dynamics of this vegetation layer is associated with the interannual variability of rainfall. In dry years, vegetation experiences little development, and some shrubs even tend to eliminate most or all of their external tissues and stop flowering. During rainy years, annuals and geophytes emerge, and shrubs renew their tissues and flower.

in_class_description_detail: Interior plain of the Atacama region and southern Antofagasta, 200–1,500 m, ultra-hyperarid mesotropical, ultra-hyperarid thermo-Mediterranean and marginally in the ultra-hyperarid hyperoceanic lower mesomediterranean bioclimatic zones. The two dominant species tend to maintain their vegetative and generative structures even during dry years, being during these periods almost the only species possible to differentiate, while the rest of the plants lose practically all their aerial organs, renewing them during the more humid periods.

in_class_description_detail: Coastal areas of the southern Atacama and northern Coquimbo regions, 0–300 m, upper thermo-Mediterranean hyper-arid and lower arid hyper-oceanic bioclimatic zones. It has been suggested that the current vegetation formations correspond to successional phases of other more developed units. In the area of ​​this vegetation level, favourable situations of greater humidity, in the absence of anthropic intervention, would lead to forest formations dominated by Lithraea caustica. Despite this, it seems that most of the area is permanently limited in its evolution, by the interannual variation of precipitation and by the low incidence of fog in the coastal areas of lower elevation.

in_class_description_detail: Inland sector of the southern Atacama and northern Coquimbo regions, 300–1,900 m, associated with the upper thermo-Mediterranean and mesomediterranean (antitropical) hyperarid and lower arid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. There are no records of the natural dynamics of this terrestrial ecosystem. Strong anthropogenic pressures, mainly for its exploitation as a dendroenergy resource, have produced severe degradation processes in this ecosystem.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior desert scrub of Heliotropium stenophyllum - Flourensia thurifera
in_class_description_detail: Arid interior zones near the coast of the central-north of the Coquimbo region, 100–900 m, in the upper thermo-Mediterranean and lower mesomediterranean arid hyper-oceanic bioclimatic floors. It has been proposed that the predominant type of vegetation in this ecosystem, where Heliotropium stenophyllum and/or Flourensia thurifera dominate, corresponds to a regressive phase of an arborescent scrubland dominated by Cordia decandra, where meadows and scrublands with a high presence of Gutierrezia resinosa correspond to the states of most severe anthropogenic disturbance. Seedling survival tends to be greater in more humid places or under the nurse effect of other plants. Changes in water availability are modulated by cycles associated with El Niño events.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior desert scrub of Flourensia thurifera - Colliguaja odorifera
in_class_description_detail: Interior of the south-central Coquimbo region, between 300 and 2,000 m. It is located in the upper thermo-Mediterranean and arid mesomediterranean and lower hyperoceanic semi-arid bioclimatic zones. It has been suggested that it corresponds to a phase of degradation of a desertified sclerophyllous forest formation, although this is not entirely supported by the climatic conditions in which it develops; it could also correspond to a natural situation resulting from a retreating desertification effect. The degradation of the typical scrubland of this ecosystem leads to an annual grassland that is colonized, in a first phase, by Gutierrezia resinosa, while the typical elements of an advanced stage of succession could be Cordia decandra in the most arid sectors and Porlieria chilensis-Quillaja saponaria in the most humid ones. The nurse effect seems to be important in the recruitment of columnar cacti such as Eulychnia acida and Trichocereus coquimbanus. The presence of seed banks allows plants, especially annual plants, to renew themselves after rain events associated with El Niño.

in_class_description_detail: Coastal zone of the central-southern Coquimbo region, 0-500 m, upper thermo-Mediterranean and lower arid mesomediterranean bioclimatic zones and lower hyperoceanic semi-arid zones. It is possible that, especially in the southern part of this ecosystem, climatic potentials allow the existence of forests or at least arborescent thickets, which have probably been eliminated from their original areas, presenting only small remnant fragments. The arid conditions of the area make a rapid recovery of such formations difficult.

in_class_description_detail: Widely distributed in the precordilleran areas of the regions of Arica and Parinacota, Tarapacá and Antofagasta, 2,500–3,300 m (northern zone) and 3,400–3,600 m (southern zone). It is associated with the supratropical ultrahyperarid, hyperarid and lower arid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones, reaching lower orotropical and, marginally, upper mesotropical positions. There is no data, but it is possible to assume that the marginal occurrence of summer rainfall would allow the regeneration of the dominant species and the renewal of the seed bank of herbaceous species.
efg_description: Semi-desert steppes on all continents are dominated by perennial shrubs, often with semi-fleshy or velvety foliage, and tussock grasses interspersed with bare ground. Low variable rainfall and extreme temperatures favour flora and fauna with drought and stress-tolerance adaptations, such as deep roots and nomadism. Growth and reproduction of shrubs and grasses is varies with rainfall, the cover of grass diminishing to near zero in extended droughts. Grass cover also depends on soil fertility and grazing animals, which may also limit shrub recruitment and growth. These steppes are among the most productive of desert ecosystems, with relatively abundant small and large herbivorous and seed-eating mammals supporting bird and mammal predators and scavengers.

in_class_description: Tropical interior desert dwarf scrub of Nolana leptophylla - Cistanthe salsoloides
in_class_description_detail: Interior of the northern Atacama region and southern Antofagasta, 1,000–2,800 m, mesotropical and supratropical ultra-hyperarid lower hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. Although there are no precedents, it must be similar to that of ecosystem 22 (interior tropical desert low scrub of Adesmia atacamensis – Cistanthe salsoloides), although with a lower recurrence and magnitude of summer rainfall, so that the options for seed recruitment are also lower.
efg_name: Succulent or Thorny deserts and semi-deserts
efg_description: Succulent or Thorny deserts and semi-deserts are restricted in their occurrence to parts of the Americas, Africa, Madagascar and south Asia. They have a sparse cover of typical cactus-like plants and other slow-growing spiny and succulent species, on stony low-nutrient soils. Many of these plants store water in their stems and have deep roots. Short-lived plant species emerge after rains from dormant organs or soil seed banks. Plants and animals tolerate extreme summer temperatures and mild winters. Nocturnal and burrowing mammals are able to avoid extreme temperatures. Diverse opportunistic invertebrates and reptiles occur, along with small numbers of large-ranging ungulates.

in_class_description: Tropical-Mediterranean Andean desert dwarf scrub of Atriplex imbricata
in_class_description_detail: Andean precordilleran zone of the Atacama region (1,500–)2,000–3,000(–3,800) m, in the supratropical and upper mesotropical (antitropical), upper ultra-hyperarid and hyper-oceanic hyperarid bioclimatic zones. It must be very similar to that indicated for ecosystem 23 (low Andean tropical desert scrub of Atriplex imbricata - Acantholippia deserticola), although with less recurrence of summer rainfall, and greater winter rainfall that triggers regeneration, but there is no verifiable information in this regard.

in_class_description_detail: Sub-Andean zone in the south of the Atacama region and north of Coquimbo, between 1,700 and 2,900 m, supra-Mediterranean and upper hyper-arid mesomediterranean and hyper-oceanic arid bioclimatic zones. There are no records on the dynamics of this vegetation level, but it is possible that it may be similar to that presented by the high Andean scrublands of the immediately superior ecosystem (see ecosystem 108, Low tropical-Mediterranean Andean scrubland of Adesmia hystrix - Ephedra breana).

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior thorny scrub of Trevoa quinquinervia - Colliguaja odorifera
in_class_description_detail: Low and medium interior mountain ranges of the Valparaíso region, between 700 and 1,500 m, in the upper thermo-Mediterranean and lower semi-arid and dry mesomediterranean hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. It is a vegetation level subject to strong anthropic pressures, so it could correspond to a phase of degradation of an original sclerophyllous forest or a tree thicket. Apparently the degradation produces a loss of cover and the expansion of Trevoa, as well as the immigration of introduced species, especially in the herbaceous stratum.
efg_description: Tropical-subtropical dry forests and thickets are characterised by fertile substrates and seasonally dry conditions (~1800 mm per year, with a period of 3 to 6 months receiving less than 100 mm per month) that drive markedly seasonal patterns of productivity. Tree-diversity is high, with a variable mixture of evergreen and drought-deciduous trees, with abundant vines, but fewer epiphytes, ferns, mosses, and forbs, limited by seasonal drought. Abundant leaf litter is decomposed by fungi and microbes within complex foodwebs dominated by vertebrates of all kinds.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior thorny scrub of Puya coerulea - Colliguaja odorifera
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the eastern slope of the Coastal Mountain Range and the Andean foothills of the Coquimbo and Valparaíso regions, 1,400–2,200 m, dry hyperoceanic supra-Mediterranean bioclimatic zone. There are no records of the dynamics of this vegetation level. It is possible that, as it is subject to mass removal processes, the colonization of sclerophyllous elements is permanently limited by these disturbances.

in_class_description: Tropical interior thorny forest of Prosopis tamarugo / Tessaria absinthiodes
in_class_description_detail: Desert pampa of the Tarapacá region, 700–1,150 m, lower hyperoceanic ultra-hyperarid mesotropical bioclimatic zone. The natural dynamics of the communities dominated by Prosopis tamarugo appear to be controlled by large floods of the pampas caused by floods from the Andes, the result of exceptional summer rainfall, which occur with a periodicity of 30 to 40 years. The water remains on the surface for a sufficient time to allow infiltration to great depths, which favors the regeneration of P. tamarugo, of which numerous seedlings were observed after floods in 1977, although this type of regeneration is very open and heterogeneous. The exploitation of water in the distribution area of ​​this species can generate decreases in the depth of the aquifer and cause water stress in the plants. It has been suggested that 20 m of aquifer depth would be the critical threshold for the survival of P. tamarugo. Many of the existing specimens have been planted artificially, but there are native formations in the Llamara salt flat.

in_class_description_detail: Large ravines in the desert pampas of the regions of Arica and Parinacota, Tarapacá and Antofagasta, 0–1,500 m, lower hyperoceanic ultra-hyperarid mesotropical bioclimatic zone. There is no known information about its natural dynamics. Most of the surfaces originally covered by this type of vegetation are now subject to agricultural use, which has ended up replacing practically all of the natural areas in the ravines.

in_class_description: Tropical Andean thorny forest of Browningia candelaris - Corryocactus brevistylus
in_class_description_detail: Precordillera of the Arica and Parinacota region and northern Tarapacá. It is located between 2,300 and 2,800 m above sea level, with a hyperarid supratropical and hyperoceanic lower arid bioclimatic zone. It extends to the department of Arequipa in Peru. It has been suggested that this ecosystem has been subject to intense exploitation, which has significantly reduced the density of columnar cacti. According to the data provided by Rosello and Belmonte, it is possible to assume that Browningia produces seeds continuously, despite the irregularity of rainfall, but due to the scarcity of juvenile specimens, recruitment must only occur after years with exceptional rainfall.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior thorny forest of Acacia caven - Prosopis chilensis
in_class_description_detail: Flat or gently sloping sectors of the intermediate depression of the O'Higgins, Metropolitan and Valparaíso regions, 200–900 m. It is located in the upper thermo-Mediterranean lower semi-arid hyperoceanic and lower mesomediterranean upper semi-arid and dry oceanic bioclimatic zones. It has been suggested that the Espinosa forest in general corresponds to a phase of degradation of the original sclerophyllous forest. At least in the case of this ecosystem, this hypothesis is doubtful, since the water conditions necessary for the presence of sclerophyllous forests (dry to wet ombrotype) are not met in most of the distribution range of this vegetation unit. The Espinosa areas are heavily disturbed and in some cases a significant loss of tree cover and even the complete transformation of the formation into a grassland can be observed. A recent contraction of the Acacia caven and Prosopis chilensis populations has been documented as a result of anthropic disturbance, which would result in the eventual disappearance of this ecosystem.

in_class_description_detail: Low slopes (foothills) of the Andes mountain range in the Metropolitan and O'Higgins regions, between 600 and 1,100 m. It is found in the semi-arid lower mesomediterranean and dry oceanic bioclimatic zones. According to the background and ecological position, it probably corresponds to a phase of degradation of the original sclerophyllous forest, which would recover in the absence of anthropic pressure.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal thorny forest of Acacia caven - Maytenus boaria
in_class_description_detail: Coastal hills in the south of the Valparaíso, Metropolitan and northern O'Higgins regions, between 0 and 400 m above sea level, dry mesomediterranean hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zone. The degradation of the Espinal forest leads to the formation of a grassland composed mainly of introduced species. It has been speculated that the Espinal forest itself corresponds to a regressive phase of the original sclerophyllous forest of Lithraea caustica and Cryptocarya alba or of the thicket of Puya berteroniana and Trichocereus chiloensis. Studies with time series of satellite images show that the degradation of the sclerophyllous forest does indeed lead to its permanent replacement by Acacia caven formations.

in_class_description_detail: Alluvial plains of the intermediate depression in the south of the O'Higgins region, the Maule region and the north of Biobío, between 100 and 600 m. Corresponds to the mesomediterranean subhumid oceanic bioclimatic zones. Some authors claim that the Espinosa corresponds to a regressive phase of the original sclerophyllous forest, which has been maintained over time due to the permanent influence of man, while others point out that it is the original vegetation. In any case, the degradation of the Espinosa forest leads to a grassland composed mainly of introduced perennial and annual herbaceous species and some shrubs.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal sclerophyllous arborescent shrubland of Peumus boldus - Schinus latifolius
in_class_description_detail: Coastal areas of the northern Valparaíso region and southern Coquimbo, 0–800 m, upper thermo-Mediterranean and lower semi-arid hyperoceanic mesomediterranean bioclimatic zones. It is likely to share characteristics with the rest of the coastal sclerophyllous forests, although in this case the degradation possibly favours the penetration of elements with desert affinities. In most of the territory the vegetation is in regressive successional states, such as Acacia caven thorn forests. Natural regeneration increases in the vicinity of patches of remaining original vegetation.
efg_name: Seasonally dry temperate heath and shrublands
efg_description: These temperate ecosystems are dominated by sclerophyll shrubs with small or ericoid leaves. A low sparse tree canopy may or may not be present. Low-moderate productivity is limited by summer droughts and low nutrient availability. and sandy or loamy soils, with many diverse plant specialisations to low nutrient, and regular fires, accelerated by slow decomposition rates. Foodwebs vary from complex to simple, but most lack large herbivores and predators. Vertebrate herbivores have specialisations to exploit low nutrient vegetation and avoid recurring fires, which are influential on plant and animal life histories. Specific plant-invertebrate relationships (e.g. as larval hosts and pollinators) are common (moths and butterflies larval hosts, wasp pollinators).

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior sclerophyllous arborescent shrubland of Quillaja saponaria / Porlieria chilensis
in_class_description_detail: Interior and Andean slopes of the regions of the Metropolitan Region of Santiago (its northern part), Valparaíso and Coquimbo, 600–1,500 m, in the semi-arid mesomediterranean and dry lower hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. It is probably similar to that mentioned for sclerophyllous forests, where the colonization of some shrub individuals creates the conditions for the immigration of other individuals, generating a horizontal, clumped structure of plant communities. Severe anthropogenic degradation leads to a thicket dominated by Gutierrezia resinosa. Flourensia thurifera thickets are probably in the intermediate phases of succession.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean sclerophyllous forest of Kageneckia angustifolia / Guindilia trinervis
in_class_description_detail: Middle slopes of the Andes mountain range in the O'Higgins, Metropolitan, Valparaíso and Coquimbo regions, between 1,400 and 2,200 m, supra-Mediterranean and upper mesomediterranean semi-arid, dry, sub-humid and lower humid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. The recruitment of Kageneckia angustifolia appears to be associated with snow accumulation. The greater amount of snow tends to delay germination and seedlings have less chance of surviving the dry season, so under pre-existing Kageneckia individuals the probability of survival is greater, since the snow accumulation is less, which would explain the spatial distribution grouped in patches. The formation of new vegetation patches occurs through mechanisms facilitating the colonizing species, which would allow colonization by tree species. The accumulation of leaf litter on the ground reduces the germination of Kageneckia and other species, although this effect is reduced compared to the nurse effect produced by the mother plants.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal sclerophyllous forest of Cryptocarya alba - Peumus boldus
in_class_description_detail: Western slopes of the Coastal Mountain Range in the Coquimbo, Valparaíso, Metropolitan and O'Higgins regions, 100–1,300 m, dry mesomediterranean and lower subhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Anthropogenic disturbances, especially recurrent fires and logging, cause degradation of the original forest, with a loss of vegetation cover, a change in the physiognomy of the community (change from forest to scrubland) and invasion of thorny and sclerophyllous scrub elements such as Retanilla trinervia, Gutierrezia resinosa, Muehlenbeckia hastulata and Baccharis linearis. In the absence of disturbances, the forest would recover from sclerophyllous elements (Lithraea caustica, Quillaja saponaria) that would generate the conditions for the re-establishment of the original dominant species Cryptocarya alba and Peumus boldus, although introduced plants, such as Pinus radiata, also favour the regeneration of native species.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal sclerophyllous forest of Lithrea caustica - Cryptocarya alba
in_class_description_detail: Low areas of the western slope of the Coastal mountain range in the Coquimbo, Valparaíso and Metropolitan regions, 0–900 m, upper thermo-Mediterranean and lower mesomediterranean bioclimatic zones, upper semi-arid and dry hyperoceanic. Similar to what was described for the previous ecosystem, where anthropogenic degradation produces a structural transformation of the forest, loss of cover and favours the immigration of more xerophytic shrub and herbaceous species; a recovery of the original vegetation would be possible in the absence of disturbances, where the presence of nurse plants plays an important role in the establishment of native plant species. In sites affected by recurrent fires, seed banks can play an important role in regeneration.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean sclerophyllous forest of Quillaja saponaria - Lithrea caustica
in_class_description_detail: Lower slopes of the Andes mountain range and the eastern slope of the Coastal mountain range in the O'Higgins, Metropolitan and Valparaíso regions, 200–1,400 m, dry mesomediterranean, subhumid and lower oceanic humid bioclimatic zones. Chile's sclerophyll forests have been subjected to strong anthropic pressures (fires, logging, grazing), which is why they are currently very degraded. The degradation of the original sclerophyll forest has the effect of a structural transformation and changes in the floristic composition, which depend on the type and level of disturbance. The first stages of degradation produce the structural transformation of forest to arborescent thicket and a penetration of more xerophytic elements such as Baccharis linearis and Muehlenbeckia hastulata. More severe disturbances could produce the complete transformation of the forest into a thorn forest dominated by Acacia caven or even into an annual grassland. Theoretically, in the absence of disturbances, these degradation communities tend to recover through facilitation mechanisms, to return to their original state, whose composition of dominant species will depend on the specific conditions of the site, especially water availability and the presence of remaining patches of original vegetation.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal sclerophyllous forest of Lithrea caustica - Azara integrifolia
in_class_description_detail: Low western slopes of the coastal mountain range in the O'Higgins, Maule and northern Biobío regions, 0–600 m altitude, under the influence of the subhumid mesomediterranean and lower humid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Repeated cutting and burning of vegetation produces effects similar to those described for the previous unit, but the grazing pressure in these coastal areas is considerably lower. It has been greatly degraded, giving way to arborescent scrubland in much of its extension, but which in some cases reaches a forest physiognomy with a fair amount of structural development, both horizontally and vertically. The presence of large extensions in adjacent areas that have been replaced by plantations of Pinus radiata causes the invasion of introduced species such as Genista monspessulana and Rosa rubiginosa. This ecosystem also constitutes the secondary scrublands replacing the deciduous forest of Nothofagus glauca and Persea lingue.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior sclerophyllous forest of Lithrea caustica - Peumus boldus
in_class_description_detail: Eastern slopes of the Coastal mountain range and intermediate depression of the O'Higgins, Maule and northern Biobío regions, between 0 and 600 m, in the subhumid mesomediterranean and lower humid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Repeated cutting and burning of vegetation produce a change in the physiognomy of the vegetation, from a forest to a sclerophyllous scrub, where the regrowth of the dominant tree species with the capacity for vegetative regeneration changes from an arboreal habit to a shrubby one, which is accompanied by the invasion of shrub species typical of drier environments such as Baccharis linearis, Muehlenbeckia hastulata or Retanilla trinervia. The grazing pressure of these environments progressively leads to a loss of the characteristic arboreal elements and the incorporation of elements of the Acacia caven thorn forest. It has been suggested that the exclusion of grazing may allow the recovery of the sclerophyllous forest.

in_class_description_detail: Low Andean slopes of the O'Higgins, Maule and northern Biobío regions, between 300 and 1,100 m, upper mesomediterranean, upper subhumid and lower oceanic humid bioclimatic zones. The dynamic patterns for this ecosystem are similar to those described for unit 43 (interior Mediterranean sclerophyllous forest of Lithraea caustica - Peumus boldus). This type of vegetation invades and replaces the disturbed areas of the adjacent deciduous forest.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior sclerophyllous forest of Quillaja saponaria / Fabiana imbricata
in_class_description_detail: Sandy areas of the intermediate depression of the Biobío region between 50 and 350 m, under the influence of the lower hyperoceanic and oceanic humid mesomediterranean bioclimatic floor. Although there is no further information on the dynamics of this ecosystem, it is possible to assume that the main source of alteration is the replacement by Pinus radiata plantations, and that the remaining areas act as recipients of introduced plants from the plantations. At the same time, anthropogenic disturbances such as fire or logging could generate secondary successional processes that allow the installation of the original components of the vegetation such as Quillaja saponaria and Fabiana imbricata.
efg_name: Seasonally dry temperate heath and shrublands
efg_description: These temperate ecosystems are dominated by sclerophyll shrubs with small or ericoid leaves. A low sparse tree canopy may or may not be present. Low-moderate productivity is limited by summer droughts and low nutrient availability. and sandy or loamy soils, with many diverse plant specialisations to low nutrient, and regular fires, accelerated by slow decomposition rates. Foodwebs vary from complex to simple, but most lack large herbivores and predators. Vertebrate herbivores have specialisations to exploit low nutrient vegetation and avoid recurring fires, which are influential on plant and animal life histories. Specific plant-invertebrate relationships (e.g. as larval hosts and pollinators) are common (moths and butterflies larval hosts, wasp pollinators).

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal deciduous forest of Nothofagus macrocarpa / Ribes punctatum
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the western slope of the Coastal mountain range in the O'Higgins, Metropolitan and Valparaíso regions, between 900 and 1,900 m, bioclimatic zones of dry upper mesomediterranean and lower hyperoceanic subhumid and upper supra-Mediterranean subhumid and lower oceanic humid. As a result of human activity, especially logging and fires, most of the forests in this ecosystem show regeneration of undergrowth, where most individuals have not reached reproductive maturity. In any case, it has been observed that, although some individuals produce seeds and some of them germinate, the seedlings do not survive and there is no regeneration.
efg_description: Oceanic cool temperate rainforests have evergreen or semi-deciduous, small-leaved trees, with conifers in some regions. These forests occupy a cooler, wetter climate than warm temperate forests (T2.4), but ocean influence promotes very high precipitation and limits persistence of winter snow (compared with T2.1 or T2.2). Tree diversity is low, but abundant epiphytic and terrestrial mosses and liverworts, ferns, lichens, and conspicuous fungi contribute to seasonal productivity. Foodwebs are simple, with low vertebrate diversity and fewer large herbivores and predators than T2.1 and T2.2, but with many species found nowhere else.

in_class_description: Mediterranean interior deciduous forest of Nothofagus obliqua - Cryptocarya alba
in_class_description_detail: Andean slopes of the southern sector of the O'Higgins and northern Maule regions and intermediate depression of the Biobío and La Araucanía regions, 0–1,000 m, in the humid hyperoceanic and oceanic mesomediterranean bioclimatic zone. The anthropogenic degradation of deciduous forests produces the formation of a thicket of quila (Chusquea quila) from which the original forest would regenerate when it is cut without the intervention of the soil. The felling and subsequent alteration of the soil by grazing allows the establishment of permanent grasslands that are later invaded by thickets of Rubus ulmifolius and Aristotelia chilensis.

in_class_description: Mediterranean-Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus obliqua - Austrocedrus chilensis
in_class_description_detail: Middle slopes of the Andes mountain range in the O'Higgins region, the Maule region and northern Biobío, 700–1,950 m, associated with the humid oceanic supra-Mediterranean bioclimatic zones. The most important factor in the dynamics of forests with Austrocedrus appears to be fire, since fires sometimes cause significant mortality of individuals. However, Austrocedrus chilensis has a good capacity to regenerate and a wide ecological tolerance to establish itself in restrictive situations and even under open canopy, especially in the northern range of distribution where populations that were not covered by glaciers appear to have high genetic variability. It is likely that anthropogenic alteration, mainly from wood extraction, generates favorable conditions for the colonization of sclerophyllous elements towards original deciduous forest situations. Extrazonal communities dominated by Nothofagus dombeyi, associated with water courses, are invaded by Rubus ulmifolius as a result of anthropogenic intervention.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal deciduous forest of Nothofagus glauca - Azara petiolaris
in_class_description_detail: Eastern slopes of the coastal mountain range in the Maule region and northern Biobío between 0 and 600 m. Corresponds to the upper subhumid mesomediterranean and lower hyperoceanic humid bioclimatic zones. Degradation of the tree canopy by logging or burning favours the colonisation of elements of the sclerophyllous forest that replace deciduous forests. More severe anthropogenic disturbances, such as harvesting of Pinus radiata plantations or complete burning of the vegetation, allow the colonisation of scrublands dominated by Genista monspessulana that impede the regeneration of the original forest. Many native species seem to be able to establish themselves in Pinus radiata plantations with different types of management.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal deciduous forest of Nothofagus glauca - Persea lingue
in_class_description_detail: Western slopes of the Coastal mountain range of the Maule region and northern Biobío between 100 and 600 m, under the influence of the upper subhumid mesomediterranean and lower hyperoceanic humid bioclimatic floor. It is very similar to that described for the Mediterranean coastal deciduous forest of Nothofagus glauca - Azara petiolaris ecosystem 49, although because these are more humid situations, the composition of the replacement communities in the event of severe disturbance could be dominated by Ulex europaeus instead of Genista monspessulana and the sclerophyllous elements that colonize the degraded forest should be more hygrophilous. However, there are no detailed studies that allow such differences to be clearly established. The establishment of sclerophyllous forests as secondary substitutes of the deciduous forest has also been reported as a possible future trend in these forests, with greater floristic transformation, an increase in the predation of Nothofagus glauca seeds and less recruitment in small fragments than in continuous forest. The background is not conclusive in indicating that Pinus radiata behaves as an invader in native forests.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus glauca - N. obliqua
in_class_description_detail: Low western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the southern Maule region and northern Biobío, between 300 and 1,000 m. It is found in the upper mesomediterranean and lower humid oceanic supramediterranean bioclimatic zones. The regeneration of deciduous individuals in the upper canopy is established cyclically by taking advantage of the light that enters the interior of the forest through the gaps in the canopy left by the collapse of the oldest individuals, forming a multi-age structure. Fajardo and Alaback conclude that Nothofagus glauca can establish itself as a pioneer in unfavorable site conditions, as well as by taking advantage of the gaps generated in mature forests. Anthropogenic degradation through mainly logging enables the establishment of even-aged saplings and the colonization of sclerophyllous elements that become dominant in situations of severe disturbance.

in_class_description_detail: Slopes of the western slope of the Coastal mountain range of the Biobío region, 10–600 m, under the influence of the humid hyperoceanic mesomediterranean bioclimatic zone. A significant proportion of the surface area has been fragmented and replaced by Pinus radiata plantations and the scarcity of studies make it very difficult to make considerations about the dynamics of this ecosystem. Some old records indicate that human intervention has led to the replacement of forests by scrublands and secondary grasslands, floristically very diversified, which in some cases retain part of their original composition, with a strong component of sclerophyllous and introduced elements.

in_class_description: Mediterranean deciduous forest of Nothofagus obliqua - Persea lingue
in_class_description_detail: Slopes and plains of the intermediate depression of the Biobío region and on the western slope of the Coastal mountain range, intermediate depression and low Andean slopes of northern La Araucanía, 0–800 m, in the humid hyperoceanic and oceanic mesomediterranean bioclimatic zone. Very similar to that described for ecosystem 47 (interior Mediterranean deciduous forest of Nothofagus obliqua - Cryptocarya alba), although due to the fact that these are more humid situations, it is possible that the bushes that invade the permanent grassland are dominated by Aristotelia chilensis and Rubus constrictus instead of Genista monspessulana.

in_class_description: Temperate deciduous forest of Nothofagus obliqua - Laurelia sempervirens
in_class_description_detail: Flat and foothill sectors of the intermediate depression of the Araucanía, Los Ríos and Los Lagos regions, 0–600 m, under the influence of the upper humid lower mesotemperate bioclimatic zones (sub-Mediterranean) and hyperoceanic hyperhumid lower mesotemperate. Some studies suggest that natural regeneration of Nothofagus obliqua requires some type of massive disturbance that generates illuminated gaps, while the accompanying laurel elements can only regenerate under canopy. This could also be true for ecosystems 47 and 53. Disturbance by logging or burning produces effects similar to those described for ecosystem 53 (Mediterranean deciduous forest of Nothofagus obliqua – Persea lingue), with replacement thickets dominated by Chusquea quila when there is no deep soil disturbance and by Rubus constrictus – Ulex europaeus or Aristotelia chilensis - Rubus constrictus when there is. Swampy areas are replaced by communities dominated by Juncus procerus. The massive flowering and death of Chusquea quila tends to favour the regeneration of semi-shade-tolerant species, but not that of Nothofagus obliqua.

in_class_description: Mediterranean-Temperate coastal mixed of Nothofagus dombeyi - N. obliqua
in_class_description_detail: Complex of deciduous, laurel and evergreen forest communities where Nothofagus dombeyi, Nothofagus obliqua and Eucryphia cordifolia alternate dominance, defining an intermediate altitudinal level on the western slope of Nahuelbuta, which form a mosaic of highly complex associations. The presence of laurel elements such as Weinmannia trichosperma, Laureliopsis philippiana, Aextoxicon punctatum, Podocarpus salignus, Caldcluvia paniculata and Persea lingue is frequent. The shrub layer is mainly composed of Gevuina avellana, Dasyphyllum diacanthoides, Ugni molinae, Luma apiculata, and the herbaceous Pilea elegans in the most humid places, while the main epiphyte is Lardizabala biternata. The natural forest cover has been heavily modified by logging and the introduction of livestock, leading to structural degradation of the vegetation and the colonisation of introduced species such as Rubus ulmifolius and Rosa moschata in the native communities.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal deciduous forest of Nothofagus alpina - Persea lingue
in_class_description_detail: Forest community dominated by Nothofagus alpina and accompanied by Nothofagus dombeyi and Nothofagus obliqua in the tree stratum and with the presence of Gevuina avellana, Persea lingue, Dasyphyllum diacanthoides and Desfontainia fulgens in the shrub stratum. It defines a clear altitudinal zone on both sides of the Nahuelbuta mountain range, in situations of high rainfall and low oceanic influence due to the effect of altitude. Ecosystem dynamics For forests dominated by Nothofagus alpina, a model has been proposed that combines small- and large-scale disturbances, where the mortality of some individuals and large patches, respectively, generates the light conditions for the natural regeneration of Nothofagus alpina. These two types of disturbances also occur at different time scales; small-scale disturbances occur in short periods of time generating multi-age structures, while large-scale disturbances occur over longer periods of time generating coeval structures. The small-scale model is also applicable to anthropogenic disturbances such as selective felling.

in_class_description: Mediterranean-Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus alpina - N. obliqua
in_class_description_detail: Western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Bío Bío region, between 800 and 1200 m. Nothofagus alpina and N. obliqua do not show continuous regeneration, maintaining, in the absence of disturbances, a co-eval upper canopy. The occurrence of large-scale disturbances promotes the recruitment of individuals of both species, which leads to structures with a marked age stratification, forming co-eval cohorts. The combined presence of sclerophyllous and laurel-like elements is possibly the consequence of a medium-term variation in the amounts of summer precipitation, typical of the Mediterranean-temperate transition, which differentially favours the expansion of the populations of one or the other elements.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus alpina - Dasyphyllum diacanthoides
in_class_description_detail: Low western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Biobío, Araucanía and Los Ríos regions, between 300 and 900 m. It is found in the upper mesotemperate and lower supratemperate upper humid and hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Part of this zone is found within the sub-Mediterranean temperate variant. It presents a coetaneous structure of Nothofagus alpina without permanent regeneration due to the cover established by the laurel species for the penetration of light into the forest. Regeneration occurs when small-scale disturbances take place (falling of trees, selective cutting), which allows the regeneration of Nothofagus alpina in the gaps, forming a multi-age structure, so that N. alpina participates in the different stages of succession; the structure of the populations of N. alpina returns to being coetaneous after larger-scale disturbances such as volcanism, fires or landslides. The anthropic intervention of the forest produces the invasion of introduced species such as Rubus ulmifolius, Rosa moschata and Acaena ovalifolia and the expansion of shrub communities dominated by Aristotelia chilensis, Rhaphithamnus spinosus and Berberis darwinii.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus alpina - N. dombeyi (M656, 1.B.2)
in_class_description_detail: Middle Andean slopes of the Biobío, Araucanía and Los Ríos regions, 700–1,300 m. Hyperoceanic and hyperoceanic lower hyperhumid supratemperate bioclimatic floor. Part of this floor is located within the sub-Mediterranean temperate variant. Also present in Argentina. The translucent upper deciduous layer favors the permanent entry of light into the interior of the forest, which on the one hand allows an important development of Chusquea culeou in the undergrowth and on the other the continuous regeneration of Nothofagus alpina and N. dombeyi, so the structure forestry tends to be multi-ethnic. Large-scale disturbances (e.g., fires, volcanism) lead to coeval structures that later become multi-ethnic due to the permanent regeneration of dominant species and the existence of smaller-scale disturbances such as falling trees or selective felling, which in turn, they contribute to the maintenance of the composition of the forest over time. The deeper and more permanent anthropic intervention of these forests produces the penetration of introduced elements such as Rumex acetosella, Prunella vulgaris and Rubus ulmifolius and the expansion of shrubby elements such as Aristotelia chilensis, Berberis darwinii and B. microphylla.

in_class_description_detail: High western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Biobío region, between 1,000 and 1,600 m, in the upper humid supra-Mediterranean and lower hyper-humid oceanic upper supra-temperate (sub-Mediterranean) bioclimatic zones. There are practically no precedents, but it could be assumed, according to the bibliography, that situations of deep anthropic intervention are replaced by permanent grasslands dominated by Euphorbia portulacoides and Rumex acetosella, which are subsequently colonized by Chusquea culeou thickets.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio - Araucaria araucana
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Biobío and Araucanía regions, between 600 and 1,400 m, upper mesotemperate and hyperhumid, hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Part of this ecosystem is located within the sub-Mediterranean temperate variant. It is also found in the north-central part of the province of Neuquén in Argentina. Evidence indicates that succession is initiated by a massive disturbance in areas invaded by Nothofagus pumilio, which forms even-aged stands that are later joined by Araucaria araucana. In the absence of massive disturbances, both Araucaria araucana and Nothofagus pumilio follow a regeneration dynamic favored by the formation of clearings, which leads to multi-aged structures of both species. Severe anthropogenic disturbances such as clear-cutting or burning lead to the formation of a grassland that is then colonized by a thicket of Chusquea culeou that later appears to be replaced by the original forest formation. González et al. conclude that fire is the main agent of disturbance that shapes the plant landscape in the area of ​​Araucaria - Nothofagus forests. The effect of fire varies according to intensity, generating secondary dynamics with the occurrence of surface fires, and primary dynamics after fires that produce the total replacement of vegetation. The former are more frequent than the latter and favour the coexistence of the dominant species.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio / Drimys andina
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Los Ríos and Los Lagos regions, between 1,000 and 1,500 m, and can reach 500 m in some areas. It is associated with the hyperhumid supratemperate hyperoceanic and lower orotemperate ultrahyperhumid oceanic bioclimatic zones. It is also present in southwest Neuquén and west of Río Negro in Argentina, 1,100–1,600 m. Regeneration is associated with massive catastrophic events such as avalanches and fires, as well as small-scale disturbances. The former create even-aged patches, under which regeneration is scarce until the forests reach mature ages. Small-scale disturbances, such as tree falls, allow the formation of gaps and the regeneration of some Nothofagus pumilio individuals, but they mostly favour Nothofagus betuloides in the sectors where they coexist, so that the structure of the forests tends to form a mosaic of even-aged patches of Nothofagus pumilio due to the action of large-scale disturbances. Populations of Nothofagus betuloides, meanwhile, tend to show a more homogeneous distribution of age classes due to more continuous regeneration. Massive death events of Chusquea generate the simultaneous takeoff of juvenile Nothofagus plants in large patches, which also results in the formation of even-aged patches.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio / Berberis ilicifolia
in_class_description_detail: Eastern slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Los Lagos and Aisén regions, Chile, between 200 and 1,200 m. It is associated with the supratemperate and upper humid orotemperate and hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Part of this zone is found within the sub-Mediterranean temperate variant. It is also found in the province of Chubut, Argentina, 900–1,400 m. Apparently, the forest does not present a continuous regeneration under the canopy and its dynamics are controlled in part by medium and large-scale disturbances, such as logging, fires, volcanic eruptions or mass landslides that lead to coeval structures in the upper stratum, with Nothofagus pumilio behaving as a colonizer of lands devoid of forest, even on massive landslides of volcanic ash. The formation of small clearings generates light environments that favor the regeneration of Nothofagus betuloides, but also that of N. pumilio, which allows the codominance of both species. The occurrence of fires alters the floristic composition of the understory and increases the probability of transformation of the forest into a thicket. It has been suggested that burned areas can be colonized by Nothofagus antarctica and N. betuloides.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio / Azara alpina
in_class_description_detail: Elevated slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Maule, Biobío and Araucanía regions, 1,400–1,800 m, supratemperate and lower orotemperate (sub-Mediterranean), upper humid and oceanic hyperhumid bioclimatic zones. In Argentina it is distributed in the northwest of the province of Neuquén, 1,600–1,900 m. There are only a few general antecedents for the formation of stunted beech forests. In areas where Nothofagus pumilio and N. antarctica coexist, the former seems to replace the latter in the absence of disturbances, due to its greater capacity to grow erect from stunted individuals. Nothofagus antarctica would be maintained in the face of disturbances such as volcanic scoria deposition and avalanches thanks to its greater capacity to tolerate extreme conditions.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio / Ribes cucullatum
in_class_description_detail: Upper slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Los Ríos, Los Lagos and Aisén regions of Chile between 1,000 and 1,500 m, but reaching up to 200 m in the southernmost areas. Also found in the provinces of Neuquén, Río Negro and Chubut in Argentina, 1,600–1,900 m. Bioclimatic zones: supratemperate and orotemperate hyperhumid to ultrahyperhumid hyperoceanic. This is exactly what has already been described for ecosystem 64 (Andean temperate deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio and Azara alpina) where large-scale disturbances typical of the vegetation limits (volcanism, avalanches) produce a greater decrease in the abundance of Nothofagus pumilio in relation to N. antarctica, and favour the altitudinal decline of the stunted formations due to the restrictive conditions generated downwards on the slope. The stunted form of the lenga and ñirre individuals is partly determined by the weight of the snow and the action of the wind on the trees in these conditions. The greater capacity of Nothofagus pumilio to recover its erect form would favour the replacement of N. antarctica by N. pumilio in situations without alteration, which would produce the rise of the lower altitudinal limit of the stunted formations.

in_class_description: Temperate-Antiboreal Andean deciduous forest of Nothofagus pumilio / Maytenus disticha
in_class_description_detail: Western Andean slope of the Magallanes region, between 100-700 m (100–900 m in the northern range of distribution), mesoboreal, supraboreal and humid orotemperate bioclimatic zones and hyperhumid lower hyperoceanic zones. Because the forest does not have shade-tolerant species under the canopy, the occurrence of disturbances at different scales causes the canopy to open and the release of regeneration. In the absence of disturbances, the fall of mature trees generates forest renewal, which tends to form coetaneous structures. It has been reported that the abrupt altitudinal limit of the forest responds to the altitudinal decrease in the survival of seedlings. Regarding disturbances caused by fires, Gaultheria mucronata sprouts profusely and the land is invaded from seeds of other species such as Ribes magellanicum and Senecio patagonicum; rhizomatous herbaceous plants such as Viola magellanica are also favored by fire. Rebertus and Veblen report the formation of partial waves in the spatial distribution of mortality/regeneration in interior forests of Tierra del Fuego, where tree fall caused by wind plays an important role. In the incidence of human alteration processes, mainly fires, the forest can be replaced by scrub dominated by Chiliotrichum diffusum and other components from the steppe.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous shrubland of Nothofagus antarctica
in_class_description_detail: High peaks of the Andes mountain range in the Los Lagos and Aisén regions, 700–1,300 m, hyperhumid orotemperate to ultrahyperhumid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zone. Although there are no direct antecedents, the floristic composition indicates that it is possible that logging causes the invasion of species of prairie grasses, which form a meadow in the face of deep disturbances. Some observations in southern Patagonia indicate that communities of Nothofagus antarctica generally have a good capacity to recover from such disturbances.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean deciduous shrubland of Nothofagus antarctica / Empetrum rubrum
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andean mountain range in the south-central part of the Aysén region and in the north of the Magallanes region, between 0 and 1,200 m. Bioclimatic zones: supra-temperate, hyperhumid oro-temperate and hyperoceanic ultra-hyperhumid. Only a few general backgrounds are available from further south or from similar communities further north. The dynamics of anthropogenic degradation are controlled in the area by fires and exploitation, allowing the artificial establishment of grasslands such as Dactylis glomerata, Holcus lanatus and Trifolium repens. There are indications that a good recovery of the original formation is possible. In deforested sites, abundant regeneration of Nothofagus antarctica is observed, which does not occur in the adult formation.

in_class_description: Mediterranean-Temperate eastern deciduous shrubland of Nothofagus antarctica / Berberis microphylla
in_class_description_detail: Low eastern Andean slopes and Patagonian margin of the Aisén region, and adjacent Argentine zones between 200 and 1,600 m, supratemperate and orotemperate (sub-Mediterranean) humid oceanic bioclimatic zones. This ecosystem has been particularly affected by grazing, which, when practiced persistently, produces the replacement of shrub species in the dominance of the communities. The ability of Nothofagus antarctica to reproduce vegetatively allows it to sprout again after fires, while the death of individuals in large areas has been interpreted alternatively as a response to aridification on the one hand or as a consequence of the state of senescence reached by the trees on the other. The occurrence of fires does not seem to affect the original floristic composition.

in_class_description: Temperate-Antiboreal Andean deciduous shrubland of Nothofagus antarctica / Chiliotrichum diffusum
in_class_description_detail: Transition between the Patagonian steppes and the deciduous forests of the Magallanes region, between 0 and 750 m, lower orotemperate, thermoboreal and hyperoceanic humid mesoboreal bioclimatic zones. It has been speculated that natural renewal occurs through the fall of senescent specimens that generate suitable light conditions for the establishment of regeneration. The degradation of the scrubland dominated by Nothofagus antarctica favours the expansion of Chiliotrichum diffusum, which can become dominant and, in cases of severe alteration, the land is invaded by elements of the Festuca gracillima steppe, with scrubland dominated by Empetrum rubrum being established in situations of extreme degradation.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal lauriphyllous forest of Aextoxicon punctatum - Laurelia sempervirens
in_class_description_detail: It is located on Mocha Island and the lower western slopes of the Nahuelbuta mountain range (Biobío region), 0–250 m, upper thermotemperate (sub-Mediterranean) humid upper hyperoceanic bioclimatic zone. This is a laurel forest, where the regeneration of the dominant tree elements of the forest is strongly conditioned by the light environments. While Aextoxicon punctatum shows the highest levels of regeneration in low-light environments, Eucryphia cordifolia shows preferences for environments of intermediate light that lead to multi-age structures due to continuous regeneration. Consequently, the opening of the tree canopy due to exploitation could produce alterations in the regenerative dynamics of the dominant species and the consequent changes in the composition and structure of the forest beyond its natural historical range. The intervened communities are apparently invaded by shrubs and even replaced by thickets dominated by Aristotelia chilensis, Chusquea quila and Rubus ulmifolius.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal lauriphyllous forest of Weinmannia trichosperma - Laureliopsis philippiana
in_class_description_detail: Low and middle slopes of the western slope of the Coastal mountain range in the Los Ríos and Los Lagos regions, between 0 and 700 m in the Pelada mountain range and 0 and 400 m in the Piuchué mountain range, in the mesotemperate and lower supratemperate hyperhumid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. In the absence of allogenic disturbances, the forest maintains a multi-age structure due to the continuous regeneration of the most shade-tolerant species. The only exception would be Weinmannia trichosperma, which exhibits a shade-intolerant behaviour similar to that of Nothofagus species, although with different growth rates; the regeneration of this species occurs in open areas, so its maintenance in mature forests would be conditioned by the formation of gaps. It has been speculated that the absence of Nothofagus in these forests is due to the absence of large-scale disturbances. In some areas this type of forest has not received massive disturbances for millennia, which has allowed it to reach a level of stability that favours the internal control of the system over energy flows and species composition.

in_class_description: Temperate interior lauriphyllous forest of Nothofagus dombeyi - Eucryphia cordifolia
in_class_description_detail:
Hills and middle slopes of the eastern slope of the Coastal mountain range, some areas of the intermediate depression and low western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the regions of La Araucanía, Los Ríos and Los Lagos, from 0 to 900 m, in the lower supratemperate and hyperhumid mesotemperate hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. Part of this ecosystem is found within the sub-Mediterranean temperate variant. Some local enclaves of this type of forest are also present in the Lago Puelo area, Argentina. 

The regeneration of the dominant species, Nothofagus dombeyi, seems to depend strongly on large-scale disturbances, whether natural or anthropogenic, such as fires, avalanches or landslides, behaving as a colonizer of lands devoid of forest. Under the canopy of Nothofagus dombeyi, species that are more tolerant to shade are associated, which colonize the gaps created by the fall of one or a few trees and remain under the canopy, increasing their dominance until the definitive disappearance of the oldest individuals of N. dombeyi. Nothofagus dombeyi and Eucryphia cordifolia are capable of regenerating in the face of small-scale disturbances caused by tree falls, when they have favorable substrate conditions and low plant densities in the undergrowth. Large-scale disturbances (e.g., alluvium, lava flows) favour the initial establishment of Racomitrium lanuginosum communities, which are later replaced by Senecio chilensis grasslands and then by Gaultheria poeppigii thickets that finally give way to forest formation. The Holcus lanatus - Agrostis tenuis grassland community appears where cattle have been introduced, which when abandoned are replaced by Rubus ulmifolius - Ulex europaeus communities. Where the forest has been cut down, secondary thickets of Aristotelia chilensis - Rubus ulmifolius appear. In the northern area of ​​this ecosystem both Nothofagus alpina and N. obliqua can be dominant in secondary forests.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal coniferous forest of Araucaria araucana
in_class_description_detail: High slopes and summits of the Nahuelbuta mountain range (Biobío and Araucanía regions), 900–1,400 m, under the influence of the lower supratemperate (sub-Mediterranean) hyperhumid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. Forest exploitation and fires determine the beginning of the primary succession, which begins with a grassland with a variable floristic composition determined by local humidity conditions. It is later colonized by a scrubland with a variable composition as well. The first forest association that follows the scrubland is composed of Gevuina, Lomatia and Escallonia, and in a later phase, the original association of Araucaria araucana and Nothofagus dombeyi is reestablished. When the fires are not so intense, a secondary successional process can occur, which begins at an intermediate stage of the described sequence. According to Veblen and Veblen et al., the regeneration of Araucaria - Nothofagus forests in Nahuelbuta is triggered by the formation of clearings, with the regeneration of Nothofagus species dependent on the formation of large clearings; there is no evidence of mutual replacement, since in forests in mature successional states both species co-dominate in the absence of large-scale disturbances.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean coniferous forest of Araucaria araucana - Nothofagus dombeyi
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Biobío and Araucanía regions, between 1,200 and 1,600 m. It is associated with the supratemperate (sub-Mediterranean) hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zone. Sites that have been subjected to massive disturbances such as volcanism and fire are successfully colonized by Nothofagus, under whose canopy Araucaria can regenerate and remain in the understory thanks to its greater tolerance to shade, which also occurs after the formation of small gaps. Araucaria individuals that remain under the canopy, however, can break free and access the upper canopy after multiple episodes of gap formation. This pattern leads to multi-age structures for Araucaria araucana, which regenerates sporadically. The long-term reproductive strategy of Araucaria as an adaptation to harsh environmental conditions contrasts with that of Nothofagus, which is more opportunistic and depends on the frequency of disturbances, generating an overlap of time scales associated with the different longevity of both species.

in_class_description: Mediterranean-Temperate Andean coniferous forest of Araucaria araucana / Festuca scabriuscula
in_class_description_detail: High slopes and plateaus on the eastern side of the Andes mountain range, between 800 and 1,500 m, in the Araucanía region, Chile, in the lower supratemperate (sub-Mediterranean) humid upper and lower hyperhumid oceanic bioclimatic zones. It is also found in the adjacent areas of the province of Neuquén, Argentina. It has been pointed out that in these types of forests fire affects the dynamics of the herbaceous and shrub layers, but that Araucaria specimens survive the fires, since due to the structure of the forest there is not enough fuel or a tree layer that allows the fire to reach the height of the crowns. Fire acts as a promoter of coexistence between tree and shrub species. It has been postulated that these forests are in decline due to climate changes that tend towards progressive aridity. On the contrary, it has also been suggested that the structure of Araucaria stands indicates a long-term dynamic as an adaptation to frequently disturbed, harsh environments.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal coniferous forest of Fitzroya cupressoides
in_class_description_detail: Peaks of the coastal mountain range of the Los Ríos and Los Lagos regions, 300–950 m, in the lower hyperhumid supratemperate and upper hyperoceanic ultra-hyperhumid bioclimatic zones. The available data indicate that the regeneration of Fitzroya cupressoides in little-disturbed forests is quite abundant in clearings, showing a multi-age structure that tends to self-replace at higher altitudes, even though the other species in the tree floristic cast also show high amounts of regeneration and are better competitors at medium altitudes. In logged forests, the regeneration of Fitzroya varies in relation to the method of exploitation. Devall et al. did not find a relationship between climate deterioration and the reduction of Fitzroya cupressoides in the last century.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean coniferous forest of Fitzroya cupressoides
in_class_description_detail: Middle and upper slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Los Lagos region and adjacent areas of Argentina, between 150 and 1,300 m, under the influence of the hyperhumid supratemperate and lower orotemperate and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. The observed patterns show that Fitzroya cupressoides regeneration is abundant in clearings and bare sites, while other dominant species such as Nothofagus nitida show continuous regeneration even under canopy, which would allow speculation about the maintenance of the forest over time with a multi-age structure of the dominant species. Fitzroya cupressoides seems to behave as a colonizer of disturbed areas, either by exploitation or by natural causes such as landslides. The longevity of Fitzroya contrasts with that of the rest of the tree cast, so that a generation of this species can coexist with several of the rest of the species. Fitzroya cupressoides regenerates sexually and vegetatively, finding an increase in vegetative regeneration positively correlated with elevation.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal coniferous forest of Pilgerodendron uvifera - Tepualia stipularis
in_class_description_detail: Gently sloping areas and flooded plains in the south of Chiloé Island, Los Lagos region, 0–350 m, hyperhumid hyperoceanic upper mesotemperate bioclimatic zone. The background indicates that the forest tends to be maintained over time due to the continuous regeneration of Pilgerodendron uviferum, which translates into multi-age forest structures where the tree canopy is not able to prevent regeneration on the forest floor. However, when Tepualia stipularis is very abundant, it can inhibit the regeneration of Pilgerodendron, which is maintained thanks to its ability to reproduce vegetatively but is eventually completely replaced. However, the presence of mature Pilgerodendron forests, with long-lived trees of more than 800 years, indicates that this forest is an advanced successional state that is maintained over time. Intervention by repeated fires produces such changes in the soil that the forest is not able to reestablish itself in those sites. As in other Pilgerodendron-dominated forests, variations in the water table could produce changes in Pilgerodendron regeneration, where this species seems to have an optimum regeneration in an intermediate range of the water table with respect to Nothofagus nitida and peatland species.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal coniferous forest of Pilgerodendron uvifera / Astelia pumila
in_class_description_detail: In the islands of the Los Chonos archipelago, Aysén region, 0–750 m, in the upper mesotemperate and lower supratemperate hyperhumid and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. As in other types of forest, fire seems to have a great importance in the dynamics of this vegetation layer. The data suggest that fires have occurred in the area since before European colonization, and that Pilgerodendron is capable of recolonizing burned sites as long as new fires do not occur that substantially modify the soil, as has been occurring since European colonization. Variations in the water table also produce variations in the forest, with abundant expansion and regeneration of Pilgerodendron with the increase in the water table due to tectonic processes, which in turn would produce a decline in the abundance of other species such as Weinmannia trichosperma and Podocarpus nubigenus. The regeneration of Pilgerodendron may be favored in mounds formed by peat bog species, where the amount of water is lower and the amount of organic matter is greater than in bare sites.
