in_class_description: Temperate Andean evergreen forest of Nothofagus dombeyi / Gaultheria phillyreifolia
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andean mountain range in the Biobío, Araucanía and northern Los Ríos regions, and very locally in the Nahuel-Huapi area in Argentina, between 1,100 and 1,600 m, in the supratemperate and orotemperate hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. The northern area of ​​this vegetation zone is under the sub-Mediterranean temperate bioclimatic variant. Its dynamics could respond to those generally studied for forests dominated by Nothofagus dombeyi (ecosystem 82: Andean temperate evergreen forest of Nothofagus dombeyi - Saxegothaea conspicua), in which the regeneration of the species is completely determined by the frequency of large-scale disturbances, leading to even-aged forests. In the absence of disturbances, Nothofagus dombeyi tends to disappear as individuals die due to senescence and dominance is assumed by other species capable of regenerating under the canopy.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean evergreen forest of Nothofagus dombeyi - Saxegothaea conspicua
in_class_description_detail: Middle western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Los Ríos and Los Lagos regions, marginally penetrating into some Argentine Andean sectors, between 0 and 1,300 m, upper mesotemperate and hyperhumid supratemperate and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. In the studied forests of this type, regeneration of Nothofagus dombeyi was not observed, but regeneration of other species was observed, in particular Saxegothaea conspicua and Laureliopsis philippiana, suggesting that in the absence of strong disturbances, these latter species tend to replace the former. The general behaviour is similar to that described for ecosystem 73 (interior temperate laurel forest of Nothofagus dombeyi - Eucryphia cordifolia). Berberis thickets are anthropogenic replacement communities in these forests.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean evergreen forest of Austrocedrus chilensis - Nothofagus dombeyi
in_class_description_detail: Marginally represented in Chile in some sectors of the southern Los Lagos region, between 200 and 1,200 m, a supratemperate hyperhumid oceanic bioclimatic zone. Its largest area of ​​dispersion is found on the slopes of the eastern slope of the Andes mountain range in the provinces of Neuquén and Río Negro in Argentina, 800–1,100 m. One of the major disturbances is fire, which causes high mortality in Austrocedrus individuals and whose recurrence seems to be influenced by human activity and short- and medium-term climatic variations. Both Nothofagus dombeyi and Austrocedrus chilensis are capable of regenerating after a fire. The formation of large gaps in young and adult forests allows the installation of regeneration of both species, leading to multi-age structures and ensuring canopy replacement. The hypothesis that Austrocedrus forests are in decline due to progressive climatic aridification has been refuted on the basis of regeneration data at the forest-steppe boundary and palynological studies. Herbivory pressure can produce changes in the composition and structure of vegetation (e.g., increased abundance of Berberis spp.) and dramatically affect Austrocedrus regeneration, as has been reported for northern Patagonia, affecting the persistence of the forest in the long term. The “Arrayanal”, small forests dominated by Luma apiculata, is the last phase of degradation of this vegetation level under conditions of intensive grazing, as reported for Argentina.
efg_description: Oceanic cool temperate rainforests have evergreen or semi-deciduous, small-leaved trees, with conifers in some regions. These forests occupy a cooler, wetter climate than warm temperate forests (T2.4), but ocean influence promotes very high precipitation and limits persistence of winter snow (compared with T2.1 or T2.2). Tree diversity is low, but abundant epiphytic and terrestrial mosses and liverworts, ferns, lichens, and conspicuous fungi contribute to seasonal productivity. Foodwebs are simple, with low vertebrate diversity and fewer large herbivores and predators than T2.1 and T2.2, but with many species found nowhere else.

in_class_description: Temperate interior evergreen forest of Nothofagus nitida - Podocarpus nubigenus
in_class_description_detail: Flooded plains of ñadis and slopes of the Los Lagos and Aisén regions, 0–700 m, associated with the mesotemperate and lower supratemperate hyperhumid and ultrahyperhumid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. The background suggests that this forest presents a relatively continuous regeneration, in contrast to most Nothofagus-dominated forests in Chile. Areas subject to large-scale disturbances are generally colonized by Nothofagus nitida and Embothrium coccineum, which allow the colonization of more tolerant species under a contemporary canopy. The permanent formation of gaps favors the regeneration of Nothofagus nitida, while the other dominant species, Podocarpus nubigenus, more tolerant than N. nitida, is able to regenerate under the canopy, suggesting a relative stability of the forest. After severe disturbances such as fires, the recruitment of woody species is favored by patches of already existing vegetation, around which the forest vegetation tends to re-establish and expand. Recruitment is also affected by environmental factors, with soil drainage being notable.

in_class_description: Temperate interior evergreen forest of Nothofagus betuloides / Desfontainia fulgens
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the western slope of the Andes in the Los Lagos and Aisén regions, between 0 and 1,100 m descending to sea level in its southern distribution range. It is found in the supratemperate and lower orotemperate hyperhumid upper and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. Apparently the shrub cover inhibits the regeneration of Nothofagus betuloides, but this species seems to be able to regenerate in small gaps, unlike the codominant species, especially Podocarpus nubigenus that regenerates well under canopy. Consequently, and in a similar way to what occurs in other Nothofagus forests, the frequency of small- and large-scale disturbances is determining the dynamics of this type of forest, alternating phases of forests dominated by a even-aged canopy and phases of multi-age structure associated respectively with massive disturbances and the formation of gaps within the forest. Human intervention leads to scrub formations dominated by Fuchsia Magellanica.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean evergreen forest of Nothofagus betuloides - Laureliopsis philippiana
in_class_description_detail: Low Andean slopes of the central-northern Los Lagos and Aisén regions, between 50 and 1200 m, under the influence of the upper mesotemperate, supratemperate and lower orotemperate hyperhumid to ultrahyperhumid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. There are no specific records on the dynamics of this ecosystem. From the existing information for other forests dominated by Nothofagus betuloides, it can be inferred that the undergrowth made up of shade-tolerant plants probably inhibits the regeneration of Nothofagus betuloides within the forest, but the formation of small gaps caused by the fall of trees or, even more, the formation of large gaps, could favor the regeneration of the species and therefore the permanence of the forest.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean evergreen forest of Nothofagus betuloides / Chusquea macrostachya
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Los Lagos and Aisén regions, between 300 and 1,200 m, descending to 50 m in some valleys, associated with the hyperhumid supratemperate and lower orotemperate and hyperoceanic and oceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. There is no direct data. Nothofagus betuloides would present a more successful regeneration in the face of medium-scale disturbances, such as the formation of large clearings, than in the creation of small clearings, where regeneration is partially inhibited by undergrowth species such as Drimys andina and Chusquea macrostachya; it may even behave as a colonizer of areas subjected to massive disturbances.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean mixed forest of Nothofagus betuloides / Berberis ilicifolia
in_class_description_detail: Middle and upper slopes of the eastern side of the Northern Ice Field in the Aisén region, between 50 and 1,200 m. It is under the influence of the supratemperate and upper humid lower orotemperate and lower hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. The dynamics of mixed forests of Nothofagus betuloides and Nothofagus pumilio have been studied in general for other localities. The regeneration of N. betuloides is more continuous than that of N. pumilio, probably due to the greater tolerance of the former to shade. Nothofagus pumilio behaves more like a colonizer after disturbances and generates the conditions for the subsequent establishment of N. betuloides, although the latter species has also been reported in early successional phases. The permanence of the mixed character of the forest would be conditioned by the frequency of medium and large-scale disturbances such as the fall of groups of trees by wind or the occurrence of mass removal events.

in_class_description: Temperate-Antiboreal Andean mixed forest of Nothofagus betuloides - Nothofagus pumilio
in_class_description_detail: Transition zone between deciduous and evergreen forests, mainly in the area of ​​Riesco Island, the Brunswick Peninsula and Tierra del Fuego, Magallanes region, between 0 and 600 m, associated with the orotemperate, upper thermoboreal and upper humid lower mesoboreal bioclimatic zones and hyperhumid lower hyperoceanic zones. There are no direct data in the area, but the dynamics of mixed forests of Nothofagus pumilio and N. betuloides have been studied in other parts of Chile. Apparently, the forest does not present a continuous regeneration under canopy and its dynamics are controlled in part by medium and large-scale disturbances such as logging, fires or mass clearings that lead to coeval structures in the upper stratum, with Nothofagus pumilio behaving as a colonizer of lands devoid of forest. The formation of small clearings generates light environments that favor the regeneration of Nothofagus betuloides, but also that of N. pumilio, which allows the codominance of both species. The colonization of deglaciated environments begins with herbaceous geophytes and hemicryptophytes, to which woody chamephytes are later added with a significant increase in herbaceous cover; At a later stage (ca. 40 years after the start of the succession) the tree species are integrated.

in_class_description: Antiboreal coastal evergreen forest of Nothofagus betuloides - Embothrium coccineum
in_class_description_detail: Eastern area of ​​the archipelago of the Magallanes region, between 0 and 500 m, supratemperate, orotemperate, thermoboreal and hyperhumid mesoboreal to hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. The exposed lands, in some cases corresponding to deglaciated areas, are colonized by Baccharis nivalis thickets, then by Gaultheria mucronata, and later by Nothofagus betuloides and Embothrium coccineum, producing a decrease in the abundance of Pernettya once the tree canopy is established and generating shade conditions that allow the establishment of other species such as Drimys winteri and Desfontainia fulgens.

in_class_description: Temperate-Antiboreal coastal evergreen forest of Nothofagus betuloides - Drimys winteri
in_class_description_detail: Territories of the archipelagos of the Aisén and Magallanes regions, wetter than the previous floor, between 0 and 350 m, supratemperate, orotemperate, thermoboreal and hyperhumid mesoboreal and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic floors. There is no data on the dynamics of this ecosystem, but based on indirect information it could be speculated that Nothofagus betuloides is a colonizer of peaty soils with the presence of Tepualia stipularis and/or Pilgerodendron uviferum, and its permanence is associated with the fall of trees that leave small clearings that allow the release of regeneration, which is otherwise inhibited by the plants present in the lower strata.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal evergreen shrubland of Pilgerodendron uvifera - Nothofagus nitida
in_class_description_detail: Oceanic islands at the western end of the Los Chonos archipelago, Aisén region, 0–650 m, in the upper mesotemperate, supratemperate and lower orotemperate hyperhumid upper and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. Despite the limited knowledge, some dynamic patterns could be similar to those indicated for ecosystem 80 (coastal temperate resinous forest of Pilgerodendron uviferum / Astelia pumila, where the regeneration of Pilgerodendron is favoured by the increase in the water table compared to other species such as Nothofagus nitida, up to a threshold where peatland species become dominant. The intensity and recurrence of anthropogenic disturbances, especially fires, probably related to variations in the water table, could determine the recovery capacity of the scrubland.

in_class_description: Temperate coastal moorland of Donatia fascicularis - Oreobolus obtusangulus
in_class_description_detail: Interior of the Las Guaitecas archipelago, Aysén region and northern area of ​​the archipelagos of the Magallanes region, 200–1,000 m, associated with the supratemperate and ultra-hyperhumid orotemperate hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. There are very few specific studies, most of them in more southern areas. The large amount of precipitation associated with cold conditions determines the accumulation of organic matter that decomposes very slowly, forming a peaty soil, which is also typical of some forest formations already described. The succession begins with the colonization of lichens, mosses and liverworts that originate a substrate on which the higher plants are later located. In the middle of the peat bog, puddles or pools of water are often found. The variation in precipitation generates oscillations in the water table where the level can drop until the pools dry up. When the puddles are filled with water, Astelia pumila and Tetroncium magellanicum seem to behave as invaders due to their greater tolerance to spending more or less prolonged periods under water. In the drier phases, there is an opportunity for colonization by tree species such as Nothofagus betuloides and Pilgerodendron uviferum, which can modify the humidity conditions of the peat bogs and cause the death of the more hygrophilous species.
efg_name: Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs
efg_description: Peat bogs in the boreal-subarctic and temperate areas of the world account for up to 40% of the world’s soil carbon. They are landscape sponges, with highly specialised plant life including shrubs, sedges and mosses equipped to grow in acidic, nutrient-poor, low-oxygen, waterlogged soils. Sphagnum moss and other peat-forming plants are foundational to these ecosystems. Insects are the dominant animal group, along with amphibians, reptiles, rodents and a few visiting birds.

in_class_description: Antiboreal coastal moorland of Astelia pumila - Donatia fascicularis
in_class_description_detail: Central zone of the archipelagos of the Magallanes region, 0–800 m, associated with the thermoboreal, mesoboreal and lower supraboreal hyperhumid and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic floors. Although there is no concrete data, this and the previous ecosystem must have very similar dynamic patterns, due to their strong floristic and physiognomic similarities. In situations of steep slopes, erosion causes the replacement of communities dominated by Donatia by those of Bolax caespitosus - Phyllachne uliginosa. The area is considered to have relatively little anthropic influence.

in_class_description_detail: Southern archipelago of the Magallanes region, 100–550 m, upper thermoboreal, mesoboreal and supraboreal hyperhumid and ultrahyperhumid hyperoceanic bioclimatic levels. There are practically no antecedents. One can only speculate that succession begins with the colonization of cryptogams that modify the substrate conditions for the subsequent colonization of higher plants.

in_class_description_detail: Eastern area of ​​the archipelago of the Aysén and Magallanes regions, forming a mosaic with evergreen and deciduous forests between 0 and 1,000 m. It is found in the supratemperate, mesoboreal and humid and hyperhumid supraboreal bioclimatic zones and hyperhumid orotemperate to hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid zones. Peat bogs dominated by sphagnum mosses correspond to the initial stage of succession. These situations are subsequently colonized by elements typical of sedge-like or cyperoid peat bogs.

in_class_description: Tropical Andean dwarf scrub of Fabiana ramulosa - Diplostephium meyenii
in_class_description_detail: Slopes of the western slope of the precordillera of the regions of Arica and Parinacota and Tarapacá, between 3,300 and 4,100 m, upper arid orotropical to lower dry hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. Navarro and Maldonado have suggested that the area has forest potential and therefore the Fabiana scrublands correspond to phases of replacement of the Polylepis rugulosa forest, the product of centuries-old anthropic intervention. In this regard, the different authors who have dealt with the subject do not agree with an interpretation of the presence of Polylepis forests in these sectors.
efg_description: Tropical alpine grasslands and herbfields are limited to a few mountainous areas of Africa, the Americas and southeast Asia. Productivity is low, limited by dry conditions, rocky substrate and nightly cold, but is not strongly seasonal. Snow and fog are common. Typical flora includes mosses, lichens, and flowering plants including distinctive megaherbs and low shrubs. Plant species have adaptations for cold dry conditions, such as tiny leaves, cushion and rosette growth forms and slow growth. Plant composition is affected by competition and facilitation between species, as well as grazing and occasional fires. Simple foodwebs include invertebrates, small mammals and reptiles, along with visiting predators and occasional herbivores from lowland savannas.

in_class_description: Tropical Andean dwarf scrub of Parastrephia lucida - Azorella compacta
in_class_description_detail: It is found mainly on rocky or stony slopes of the Andean mountain range in the regions of Arica and Parinacota and Tarapacá, between 4,300 and 4,600 m. It is found in the upper orotropical and lower cryorotropical subhumid upper and lower humid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. It is also found in southern Peru, Bolivia and Argentina. This community has suffered degradation due to intensive extraction of firewood by the inhabitants of the area. Apparently, degraded areas tend to show an increase in the abundance of Pycnophyllum bryoides and a decrease in the other species. There are no records of its natural regeneration dynamics, but the presence of cushion plants (Azorella compacta) and tufted grasses (Festuca orthophylla) suggests that these are colonizers in the initial phases of succession and that they act as nurse plants that facilitate the establishment of other species. Navarro and Maldonado have suggested that the thickets correspond to replacement phases of Polylepis tarapacana forests.

in_class_description: Tropical Andean dwarf scrub of Parastrephia lucida / Festuca orthophylla
in_class_description_detail: Slopes, hills and plains of the Altiplano of the regions of Arica and Parinacota and Tarapacá, between 4,000 and 5,000 m above sea level, with bioclimatic zones of upper orotropical and lower cryorotropical, upper subhumid and lower humid hyperoceanic. It is also found in the Puna of Bolivia and Argentina. The available information is very scarce, but it is possible that in some aspects it is very similar to the previously described ecosystem (low tropical Andean scrub of Parastrephia lucida - Azorella compacta), due to the presence of numerous cushion plants and tufted grasses. Excessive grazing pressure, especially on flat land where grasses are abundant, seems to produce an increase in the abundance of Tetraglochin cristatum in relation to the other species. Navarro and Maldonado have suggested that the scrublands correspond to replacement phases of Polylepis tarapacana forests.

in_class_description: Tropical Andean dwarf scrub of Parastrephia lepidophylla - P. qudrangularis
in_class_description_detail: Altiplano of the Arica and Parinacota and Tarapacá regions, between 3,900 and 4,700 m, upper orotropical and lower dry cryorotropical and hyperoceanic subhumid bioclimatic zones. Also present in Bolivia. The strong grazing pressure on areas with abundant grasses causes a decrease in these, accompanied by an increase in the abundance of Tetraglochin cristatum and/or Pycnophyllum bryoides, species that, if present in large quantities, could be used as indicators of degradation. In relation to natural dynamics, it is possible that, as has been pointed out for other high Andean ecosystems, some colonizing plants (Festuca orthophylla) act as nurse plants that allow the establishment of other species.

Cushion plants are probably colonizers of open land and facilitate the immigration of other species that use them as nurse plants.

efg_description: Tropical alpine grasslands and herbfields are limited to a few mountainous areas of Africa, the Americas and southeast Asia. Productivity is low, limited by dry conditions, rocky substrate and nightly cold, but is not strongly seasonal. Snow and fog are common. Typical flora includes mosses, lichens, and flowering plants including distinctive megaherbs and low shrubs. Plant species have adaptations for cold dry conditions, such as tiny leaves, cushion and rosette growth forms and slow growth. Plant composition is affected by competition and facilitation between species, as well as grazing and occasional fires. Simple foodwebs include invertebrates, small mammals and reptiles, along with visiting predators and occasional herbivores from lowland savannas.

in_class_description: Tropical Andean dwarf scrub of Mulinum crassifolium - Urbania pappigera
in_class_description_detail: Widely distributed in the high mountainous areas of the Andes in the south of the Tarapacá region, Antofagasta and northern Atacama, between 4,000 and 4,800 m. Bioclimatic zones: orotropical and lower arid cryorotropical and hyperoceanic semiarid. As has been noted for other Andean ecosystems, cushion plants and tufted grasses likely act as colonizers and then allow the arrival of other species through their nurse effect.

in_class_description: Tropical-Mediterranean Andean dwarf scrub of Adesmia hystrix - Ephedra breana
in_class_description_detail: Middle Andean slopes of the Atacama and Coquimbo regions, 1,900–3,400 m, supratropical, orotropical (antitropical) and upper hyperarid lower oro-Mediterranean to lower hyperoceanic semiarid bioclimatic zones. There are no records on its dynamics, but due to its ecological position and physiognomy it is likely that it has some common features with the rest of the supra-Mediterranean low scrublands.
efg_description: Temperate alpine grasslands and shrublands occur above the treeline, on temperate and boreal mountains worldwide. Seasonal productivity is limited by cold and snow cover, often with strong winds. Mosses, liverworts, lichens, flowering plants and low shrubs generally form a continuous cover, except where strong winds and dry conditions limit vegetation to sparse lichens and dwarf shrubs. Most fauna is seasonally active during warmer summer months, with insects and vertebrates having adaptations to extreme cold, including hibernation. Many species have restricted distributions, with strong barriers to dispersal between mountains.

in_class_description: Tropical-Mediterranean Andean dwarf scrub of Adesmia subterranea - Adesmia echinus
in_class_description_detail: High slopes of the Andean mountain range in the Atacama and Coquimbo regions, 3,000–3,800 m, arid, semiarid and dry lower hyperoceanic orotropical (antitropical) bioclimatic zones. Cushion plants, such as Adesmia subterranea and Azorella madreporica, act as nurse plants that generate microenvironmental conditions that favor the immigration of other species, especially herbaceous ones.

in_class_description: Mediterranean coastal dwarf scrub of Chuquiraga oppositifolia - Mulinum spinosum
in_class_description_detail: Rocky peaks of the high mountains of the Coastal mountain range of the O'Higgins, Metropolitan and Valparaíso regions, over 1,800 m, in the supra-Mediterranean and lower oro-Mediterranean, upper subhumid and humid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Since this type of vegetation only develops under cold conditions in the upper parts of the mountains, it is probably in natural decline due to the increase in aridity and temperature typical of the interglacial period in which we find ourselves and its reinforcement by anthropic causes. In this regard, some places seem to be colonized by elements from thorny scrub (eg, Puya coerulea). There is no further information on its regenerative dynamics, but it is very likely that it is very similar to that of the low Andean scrub dominated by Chuquiraga oppositifolia.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean dwarf scrub of Chuquiraga oppositifolia - Nardophyllum lanatum
in_class_description_detail: Widely distributed on the high slopes of the Andes mountain range in the O'Higgins, Metropolitan, Valparaíso and southern Coquimbo regions, 1,600–2,900 m, dry, subhumid and humid hyperoceanic and oceanic supra-Mediterranean and lower oro-Mediterranean bioclimatic zones. Mesoscale disturbances such as mass removal events may be acting permanently, limiting the progress of succession, although it is not possible, with current knowledge, to identify which are the pioneer species. Direct observations on the floristic composition reveal the presence of a set of introduced species associated with livestock.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean dwarf scrub of Laretia acaulis - Berberis empetrifolia
in_class_description_detail: High western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the north of the Biobío, Maule, O'Higgins, Metropolitan Santiago and Valparaíso regions and south of Coquimbo, between 1,800 and 2,600 m in the south and 2,600 and 3,300 m in the north, in the upper dry oro-Mediterranean to hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. Also present in adjacent areas of Argentina. Severe climatic conditions, high solar radiation, low temperatures and strong winds determine the physiognomy of the vegetation. Plants occupy protected biotopes and facilitation relationships are frequent, where cushion plants (eg, Laretia acaulis, Azorella madreporica and A. monantha) act as nurse plants for the regeneration and development of other plants, both native and introduced, with cushion plants possibly being the first colonisers of uncovered lands. These facilitation relationships depend on the environmental context and the nurse species. It is possible that livestock pressure produces an alteration of the structure and composition of the vegetation, decreasing its cover and causing the invasion of introduced species.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean dwarf scrub of Chuquiraga oppositifolia - Discaria articulata
in_class_description_detail: Middle and upper western slopes of the Andes mountain range in the Maule region, between 1,200 and 2,300 m, in the upper supra-Mediterranean and lower humid and hyper-humid oceanic oro-Mediterranean bioclimatic zone. There are no data, but it is possible to infer that anthropogenic pressure from grazing or firewood extraction produces a loss of vegetation cover and the introduction of allogenic species. Because soil development is naturally incipient, it is likely that in the absence of anthropogenic disturbances the plants are capable of recolonizing the land from which they were eliminated. Surely several aspects of the dynamics are similar to the ecosystem of the Mediterranean low Andean scrub of Chuquiraga oppositifolia - Nardophyllum lanatum.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean dwarf scrub of Discaria chacaye / Berberis empetrifolia
in_class_description_detail: High parts of the Andes mountain range in the Biobío and Araucanía regions, between 1,600 and 2,300 m. In Argentina, in the high areas of the Andes mountain range in the province of Neuquén, between 1,600 and 2,200 m. It is associated with the upper supratemperate and lower orotemperate (sub-Mediterranean) hyperhumid oceanic bioclimatic zones. The spectrum of life forms in this vegetation level suggests that the colonization of bare ground is mainly colonized by cushion plants that act as nurse plants for the colonization of other species, with a progressive increase in species richness, as occurs in other high Andean environments. It is possible that grazing pressure produces an increase in the relative importance of the shrub life form to the detriment of grasses.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean dwarf scrub of Adesmia longipes - Senecio bipontinii
in_class_description_detail: High sectors of the volcanic cones of the Biobío, Araucanía, Los Ríos and Los Lagos regions, between 1,300 and 2,500 m and in Argentina in the high areas of the Andes mountain range in the provinces of Río Negro, Chubut and southern Neuquén, between 1,500 and 2,000 m. Hyperhumid orotemperate and hyperoceanic ultra-hyperhumid bioclimatic zones. The progressive recruitment of species results in a stable increase in species richness over time. The first species to colonize the bare ground are algae and then lichens, which modify the soil environment, generating the conditions for the immigration of the first vascular plants, which correspond to cushion plants or dwarf shrubs, which again modify the soil and act as nurse plants for the other species, allowing for an increase in richness and changes in the floristic composition.

in_class_description: Antiboreal Andean dwarf scrub of Bolax gummifera - Azorella selago
in_class_description_detail: High areas of the hills of the Magallanes region, between 500 and 800 m, reaching up to 200 m in the southernmost area. Upper mesoboreal, supraboreal, hyperhumid oroboreal and hyperoceanic ultrahyperhumid bioclimatic zones. There is no direct data, but since this is a type of high Andean vegetation with pulvinate plants, it is possible that these are the ones that initiate colonization, generating a nurse effect for the subsequent establishment of other species. Some recently deglaciated areas are colonized by Nothofagus antarctica and N. betuloides. Persistent seed banks have been reported for this type of vegetation.

in_class_description: Tropical-Mediterranean Andean forb vegetation of Chaetanthera sphaeroidalis
in_class_description_detail: Upper parts of the Andes mountain range in the regions of Atacama and southern Antofagasta and northern Coquimbo, above 4,000 (3,400) m, arid, semiarid and dry hyperoceanic orotropical and cryorotropical bioclimatic zones. It is also present in the high mountain ranges of the adjacent areas of Argentina and Bolivia. Much of this ecosystem is found in the tropical antitropical variant. There is no direct data. Soils are subject to permanent processes of gelifraction, so that the dynamics depend on the recurrence of this type of disturbance. Succession probably never goes beyond the colonization stage.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean forb vegetation of Nastanthus spathulatus - Menonvillea spathulata
in_class_description_detail: Elevated sectors of the Andes mountain range, over 2,700 m, in the O'Higgins, Metropolitan, Valparaíso and southern Coquimbo regions, oro-Mediterranean and cryoro-Mediterranean subhumid, humid and hyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic bioclimatic zones. There is specific evidence showing that pollination and dispersal syndromes of plants are predominantly abiotic at high altitudes, probably favouring autogamy and influencing the regenerative dynamics of vegetation, but it seems that it is not known exactly how these influences operate. It has been shown that annual plants tend to form persistent seed banks more frequently than perennial plants, in response to seasonal variation in snow cover. Mass removal processes are permanent, favouring spatial mobility of seeds and are permanently limiting the advance of succession.

in_class_description: Mediterranean Andean forb vegetation of Oxalis adenophylla - Pozoa coriacea
in_class_description_detail: High western slopes of the Andes mountain range, in the Maule region, above 2,500 m, in the upper oro-Mediterranean, upper humid cryoro-Mediterranean and oceanic hyperhumid bioclimatic zones. It is also present in Argentina. The substrate is subjected to gelation processes that result in the total elimination of vegetation. Plants tend to settle in areas protected from low temperatures where moisture accumulates, i.e. between or under rocks. The first colonizers are probably cushion plants, which act as nurse plants and allow the arrival of other species, and small perennial herbs that can be introduced between rocks.

in_class_description: Temperate Andean forb vegetation of Nassauvia dentata - Senecio portalesianus
in_class_description_detail: High mountainous areas of the regions of Los Lagos, Aisén and northern Magallanes, Chile, above 500 (1,200) m. Bioclimatic zones of upper humid orotemperate and cryorotemperate (sub-Mediterranean), hyperhumid and ultrahyperhumid hyperoceanic and oceanic. It is also present in the high areas of the Andes mountain range in the provinces of Río Negro and Chubut, Argentina, above 1,500 m. There are no precedents, but it is possible that due to the environmental situation of altitude in which they are found, the soils and the rock are subject to gelifraction processes that produce the total elimination of the vegetation, which is colonizing the most protected lands and those with greater soil humidity, i.e. between the rocks or in the cracks where the formation of a very incipient soil is possible.

in_class_description: Mediterranean-Temperate eastern steppe of Festuca pallescens / Mulinum spinosum
in_class_description_detail: Plains and foothills of the eastern slope of the Andes mountain range in the Aisén region, 200-1,300 m, associated with the oro-Mediterranean and oro-temperate (sub-Mediterranean) subhumid and humid oceanic bioclimatic zones. Towards the east it is most widely expressed in the provinces of Río Negro and Chubut (Argentina). The recruitment of young plants seems to be determined by the availability of seeds in the soil, which is higher in places where other plants already exist or near them versus bare areas. This pattern has been evaluated in Bromus setifolius, showing that the presence of a seed bank is the most important factor in recruitment. Although bare sites are more favorable for the establishment of new plants, the role played by the spatial distribution of seed availability tends to reinforce the distribution pattern of preexisting vegetation. It has been suggested that this pattern can be extended to the rest of the dominant species of the steppe. It has been established that the effects of livestock farming generate a regressive successional process in which the importance of shrubs increases and that of grasses and herbaceous legumes decreases.
efg_description: Temperate subhumid grasslands are simple in structure, composed of tussock grasses with scattered forbs, with few isolated trees and shrubs. Cold winters with occasional to frequent snow and frost limit the growing season, but hot dry summers create water stress. Nonetheless, fertile soils enable high productivity after rains, supporting a complex foodweb of invertebrates, ground-nesting birds, burrowing mammals, large herbivores, reptiles and predators. Large herbivores graze heavily, range widely, and are important in maintaining coexistence of plant species and nutrient cycling, as are periodic fires.

in_class_description: Mediterranean eastern steppe of Festuca gracillima
in_class_description_detail: Southeastern sector of the Magallanes region, between 0 and 300 m, oro-Mediterranean and lower oro-temperate (sub-Mediterranean) dry upper and lower sub-humid hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. Some indirect evidence indicates that anthropogenic degradation of the Festuca gracillima steppe, especially due to grazing, leads to the loss of grass cover and the expansion of shrubs. In Argentine sectors, it has been observed that the indicators of degradation are mainly Nardophyllum bryoides and Mulinum spinosum.

in_class_description: Mediterranean eastern steppe of Festuca gracillima / Mulinum spinosum
in_class_description_detail: Central eastern and southeastern sector of the Magallanes region, between 0 and 650 m, in the oro-Mediterranean and oro-temperate (sub-Mediterranean) lower subhumid lower hyperoceanic bioclimatic zones. Empetrum rubrum is one of the colonizers of disturbed bare soils, but colonization occurs from plants that germinate in undisturbed soils and then advance over the bare lands. In the areas of contact with the deciduous forest, this ecosystem could correspond to a degraded state of the forest due to centuries-old anthropic intervention of logging and burning.

in_class_description: Temperate eastern steppe of Festuca gracillima / Chiliotrichum diffusum
in_class_description_detail: Southeastern sector of the Magallanes region, 0–450 m, in the subhumid lower orotemperate (sub-Mediterranean) and hyperoceanic lower humid bioclimatic zones. There is no concrete information on the dynamics, but it is known that from a floristic point of view this ecosystem corresponds to transitional situations between the Patagonian steppe and the scrublands and deciduous forests. In this regard, it could be speculated that these are formations derived from the forests, the product of centuries-old anthropic intervention, especially livestock farming, which favors the penetration of some elements of the steppe.
